request_pathways.name: UPMC Authorization for Release of PHI
Mail completed form to UPMC facility

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use the system-wide UPMC generic ROI authorization form, selecting 'Personal Use' as the purpose and listing themselves as the recipient.

red_flags: Fee language does not distinguish patient access from third-party requests and implies conditioning records release on upfront payment
90-day default authorization expiration is unusually short
bright_spots: Inline note 'Purpose is not required for patient access' clearly acknowledges HIPAA individual access rights
Companion instruction guide (form-3.pdf) with plain-language explanations and examples is a rare patient-friendly resource
Email and Direct Address electronic delivery options for records
Explicit anti-conditioning statement on treatment, payment, and enrollment
Oral authorization provision for patients physically unable to sign

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation or a simple search — web searches immediately returned direct PDF links, and the form is linked from both the system-wide and facility-specific medical records pages with no difficulties.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — despite being born-digital, the form has essentially no fillable fields (1 unnamed field detected), requiring patients to print, handwrite all ~20 data points, and submit physically; no online submission portal exists.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but has notable problems — the logical section structure (A-B-C) and companion instruction guide are positives, but page 1 is extremely dense with 20+ record-type checkboxes, tight spacing, and mixed plain/legal language that could overwhelm patients.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the form is a generic third-party release authorization with no dedicated patient access pathway, though the 'Purpose is not required for patient access' note and 'Personal Use' option partially accommodate self-access.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements or language that may go beyond what the law requires — fee language citing PA state law doesn't distinguish patient access fees from third-party fees, 'records will be sent upon receipt of payment' may conflict with HIPAA's timely access requirement, and the 90-day default expiration is unnecessarily restrictive.

overall.summary: UPMC Presbyterian provides an easy-to-find generic ROI form with some patient-friendly features (companion guide, purpose-not-required note) but is held back by a non-fillable paper workflow, no dedicated patient access pathway, and ambiguous fee language.
